title: How to Enable a Manufacturing Renaissance

rawLines.text: Why don't you give like a 60cond intro
about what you're building? So, my name
is Ian Cinnamon. I'm the CEO and
co-founder of a company called Apex. And
essentially, we are ensuring that the US
and the West wins the new space race
that we are in the middle of today. Uh,
as Brian you mentioned earlier, uh,
China is far surpassing the US and our
allies in their ability to produce
spacecraft at scale. The CCP has
announced plans to launch over 13,000
government satellites in the coming
years. The US government launched barely
over 200 last year. We need to catch up
by orders of magnitude. And at Apex,
we're building the core platform for
these satellites, known in the industry
as the satellite bus, to power the wave
of proliferated space. So we can build
these very rapidly at our facility in
Los Angeles. Uh our company is a little
bit over two years old. Uh we're very
fortunate to have uh our uh satellites
in orbit. Uh dozens of satellites
ordered by customers and uh fortunate to
have Andre Horwitz as our largest
shareholder.
And Chris, tell us about Hrien. Uh so
I'm Chris. I'm the CEO and founder of
Hadrien. We build uh automated factories
for the aerospace and defense industry.
So our customers are the big primes and
neopimes like SpaceX and Andreal as well
as a lot of the startups in this room
that are trying to go fast. And um the
thesis of the company is basically if if
people don't know this most of the
skilled labor in the defense industrial
base is 62 years old that makes the
components or widgets that end up
getting assembled into drones, fighter
jets, missiles, um any hardware that we
need to put in the air, on the sea or on
the land for deterrence. It's about $200
billion in manufacturing in the US. Um,
but it's all being done by 62 year olds
who are incredibly highly skilled and
aging out. Um, and actually the the vice
president nailed it this morning, which
is the point is how do you compete with
China on global manufacturing? And the
answer is with software and AI and
robotics that give the American worker
superpowers. Um, so we enable all of our
customers to go a lot faster and a lot
cheaper and at a price point where we
can onshore um, both in our facilities
in LA and across the country now as
well. dedicated facilities for the
federal government or major programs
where you can think about us as like we
will build and operate UA Tesla
Gigafactory
um so that you are spinning out ships
and missiles or whatever product set has
constrained manufacturing in the US as
fast as humanly possible. So Chris, why
we're all in Los Angeles as a start and
we're probably not there for the taxes
or the wildfire management practices. So
why why LA for us? I mean it was the
people and you mentioned like the the
the workforce is aging but the talent in
LA for like all the various aerospace
disciplines and for even the technicians
but so what why why are you guys based
in LA? We we will scale outside of
California very quickly but the
inception of the company basically had
to be half Silicon Valley half
manufacturing. Um and we need to combine
those two cultures together and Sham
actually nails this is like you got to
have your engineers with your
manufacturing. for us that's I have to
have my software engineers on the
factory floor automating things and
that's how you build really good
product. They have to be literally
running the stuff themselves otherwise
the context is not there. Um and LA was
the perfect place where we could pull
enough uh software and robotics talent
down from Silicon Valley and with
massive companies like um SpaceX and
Androl already in LA. There is a huge
manufacturing base there. So it was
about the combination of those two
cultures to go 0ero to one on all our
autonomous systems. Ian, how about you?
So when I started Apex, we had a very
particular point of view on the types of
people that we wanted to bring together
and where we needed to be. And we wanted
to combine the world's best of
traditional engineering and
manufacturing with what we call new
space companies like SpaceX or others in
the industry and combine that with
frankly non-erospace as well. And
there's really only one place on the
planet that has all three of those and
that is Los Angeles. Right? We're able
to build about a third of our team or
now about half of our team from
companies like SpaceX, a huge chunk of
our team from traditional aerospace that
brings a lot of great mentality and then
non-space like myself. I come from a
software background. Um, and we wanted
to colllocate that alongside our
customers. And when you look at where
the major defense primes are, we act as
a merchant supplier to the defense
primes. We have folks like Andril or
Northrup or Lockheed or Boeing right in
our backyard. And we have our end
customers like Space Systems Command 7
minutes from our office. So for us, it
wasn't really an option. It was the
obvious choice of where we needed to be.
So we're on the topic of LA and Chris,
we've talked about this before. We both
suffer through maybe Ian, you do too.
You're in Culver, so I don't know if you
get the the benefits of Southern
California Edison, which is the local
power company. Um the power rates in
California are ridiculously high. even
if you tell them I will just pay you
hundreds of thousands per month to buy
megawatts of power, they argue with you,
tell you you don't need you don't need
power. Um, and so I'd say like one of
the things that like we experienced in
in LA is I literally tried to bribe a
line crew to install larger KVA
transformers on the pole than the
poultry ones that they were putting in
uh unsuccessfully sadly. But this for us
is like going to be a reason that that
we will end up not manufacturing in LA.
So I think like what do you guys see is
like if you want to like host businesses
like like these and like be supportive
from a policy perspective like what
types of things have you guys seen that
have been a problem that you would want
to address? So I will I will say that we
we built a 100,000 square foot in LA and
then we're going to launch two new
facilities next year which are about
half a million square foot each and then
we'll keep expanding to every state. Um,
and as an example, and I actually think
the current administration um, really
knows what they're doing here. 3 years
ago, I would not have told you this is
how much time it was spent, but I think
we designed and launched the actual
building and all the construction in 3
months and then sat around waiting for
permits and energy for 6 to 9 months.
Um, and probably had to put more
documentation together to convince
Southern California Edison to give me
8,000 amps to the building than the
documentation I had to give our lawyers
to do $100 million series B. and you
can't pay any money just to get power,
energy or permitting done. Um whereas
there are more friendly states out there
with better grids and stuff like that
and you know we have a lot of robots, we
have a lot of machines, we have a lot of
people like we just need this
infrastructure there. Yeah, we had the
mayor Sagundo call them on our behalf
and he was told to go away. Yes. Which
is pretty impressive.
What do you say? Doge into the power
company. Yeah. I mean look, we're we're
in the same boat, right? We uh we moved
to uh P Vista, so we're still in Los
Angeles now. No more Culver City. And
it's the same thing, right? Um, we got
our building, we filed for our permits,
we waited 9 months, no permits, 10
months in, we got our permits, and then
it took 4 weeks to build out the
building. Like, that's not how it should
be. That being said, I think I have a
little bit of a different take than the
two of you. Um, we are manufacturing in
Los Angeles and we're going to expand
and manufacture in other parts of not
just the US, but allied nations as well.
And we're going to keep manufacturing in
California and Los Angeles. And I really
believe that no matter where you go,
there's always going to be problems,
right? There's always some issue left or
right. I'll be honest, we have the same
power problems that you guys have.
Running these uh shaker tables uh takes
a little bit of power. Um we're actually
working on getting the lease of the
building next door to us that is wired
for a lot more power than our building
literally just to use the power. Like
that is the extent that we're going to.
So is it a problem? It's a massive
problem, but um yeah, we're working to
mitigate it. No one ever tells you what
you're going to be doing. Uh trying to
run a manufacturing business, but it's
just literally one day the next trying
to weasle your way through. Um and I
this is like if if you want to look at
like where like at least we're looking
to expand just having an environment
where things like the basics power,
water, regulatory licensing because I
think for us like one of the biggest
issues has been licensing uncertainty.
uh you can literally go and deploy a lot
of capital to build out facilities and
like we we're we're we make missiles, we
have energetics. I don't want to invest
in an area if I don't know if I'm going
to actually get the final permit to use
the factory. Um and that just then slows
everything down. So working with
jurisdictions for us with that give out
regulatory certainty is like by far the
most important. And I will say Elskundo
has been phenomenal, but like California
controls a lot. Um and I think there's
some improvements that could be made
there. So um let's go to what you've
seen over the past like say three years.
We are at the American Dynamism Summit
and for us I've seen like a huge shift.
I'd love to get your take of like what
what shift have you seen in terms of
like this movement actually like
empowering change from where you
started? I think it's insanely
accelerating. Um and for those of you
don't don't know the American dynamism
practice at Andre is about 3 years old.
Um, and historically, I would say 10 to
20 years ago, there were companies like
SpaceX and Palanteer, more recently
Andrew, who I think is about eight or
nine years old. And then was there was a
wave of very patriotic companies in kind
of our era when we're about four years
old now. um that were really realized
that manufacturing and the national
security mission were critically
important to the country and like how
would we ever even attempt to think
about building a software company
because this was just so important even
though it's incredibly difficult as Mark
Andre likes to says you know these hard
tech businesses are on hard mode and
he's absolutely correct um but for us
like kind of the early people who just
cared about the mission it was it was
never about like hopping onto a movement
that already existed um and then you got
folks like uh Katherine and and David
Yulovich that really also believed in
the same thing and the fund and the
practice kind of started at the same
time and now in the last 2 to 3 years I
would say the number one thing is 3
years ago for very young talent or
software engineers it was like
convincing them that manufacturing or
national security was incredibly
important and now I think if you're
starting a startup I think if you're a
software engineer actually most of what
I hear from people today is like I
actually don't want to go work at Google
I want to go work at SpaceX I want to go
work at Android I want to work at Hrien
And I think the mission building here
from how many Americans want to work on
these hard problems from leaders like
Catherine and Mark and Ben and DU from
like really sending that message out has
taken this from kind of really only 10
companies that are true believers to now
this enormous ecosystem of hundreds and
hundreds of companies um that are
getting sprung up around American
manufacturing and American dynamism. So
it's been it's it's incredible to see
just a few short years of how fast this
has gone. It has shifted a lot. Ian,
anything you want to add to that? Yeah,
I mean 10 years ago, I started a company
that was building AI and computer vision
software for different national security
applications and we built the company in
Palo Alto, California. And I remember
every single day we were worried about
protesters standing outside our doorstep
coming over from Stanford or wherever
they may have been to say, "How dare you
work with the government?" And then I
remember about uh 5 years ago in 2020 um
I I sold the company to Palunteer and
around that time there were protesters
lining up outside Palanteer's office in
Palo Alto and the company ended up
relocating its headquarters. And then I
remember two years ago when Chris and I
were at the first American Dynamism
Summit sitting right here, um it started
to shift, right? And I think Katherine
and David were were early and Andre was
obviously early to this trend and
realized that there was a a shift
happening. Um and it started to be
something where it's like, wait a
minute, like you can actually make an
impact on the world. You can make a
change by doing this. And now um I look
and I I'm entertained because it looks
like uh every investor around the world
thinks it's cool and sexy to go do
defense tech and all of that. And look,
you have a lot of people maybe putting
money where they shouldn't and to
science projects or ideas that are not
very real or they don't understand the
end customer. But for the companies that
have been in it from the beginning and
the investors who have been in this from
the beginning and understand it, I mean,
I think we're still at the very
beginning of this wave. Yeah, I I
completely agree. So when we started the
business and obviously we're building
missiles is a bit of an aggressive idea
like thought we could raise money wasn't
100% sure it was very possible just
going to become unemployed. Um but we
couldn't even get a bank account. We
tried to open a bank account and they
just got dumped into like well you're
you're you're basically the same as porn
and uh gambling so we're not going to
give you a bank account. And I was like
okay well how how do I even start the
business? I can't even get a bank
account. Only hypersonics. SVB said yes.
And then the next week they went
bankrupt.
should have done it with Bitcoin, but it
was a panicked moment. But um uh you
know, I think like this concept of like
defense tech, manufacturing, all of it,
hardware is cool again. Would you have
ever thought 3 years ago the vice
president of the United States is
standing up on stage at the American
Dynamism Summit talking about the
American manufacturing workforce and how
important it is to re-industrialize the
country. Honestly, it's fantastic. I
think if you told me this three years
ago, I wouldn't have. Yeah, I wouldn't
have either. And I've always been like I
I as a mechanical engineer like I get
why software is so important but my god
there's there's nothing worse than just
arguing with code and having it not run
but making something I it's just
difficult. And I'd love to hear like
your guys' take of like what's the
biggest challenges like we all make very
different things but they're complex
things. Like what's your biggest
challenges that you see? So Ian maybe
take that like what what's the hardest
part of scaling up manufacturing
satellites? Yeah, frankly there's
there's two pieces right. So, one of
them, I mean, thank you Chris for
starting Adrian because you address a
lot of these problems, but um the supply
chain is a nightmare, right? You're
dealing with a bunch of tier two and
three suppliers who are frankly mom and
pop shops, which good for them, right?
They did a phenomenal job creating this
industry. But when you realize that they
were built around the premise of let's
go put a few bespoke exquisite systems
into space or into whatever domain you
want to operate in not let's move
towards proliferation and put hundreds
or thousands of systems into orbit
everything breaks down. So uh that you
know we like to say at Apex the hardest
part about building a satellite is
having the parts to go build that
satellite. If you don't have the parts
it's not happening. The second thing
that frankly I think is one of the most
undervalued pieces of any hardware
system and both Chris and Brian have
mentioned it already today uh is
software and I think a lot of people
forget that if you have a bunch of
hardware parts that don't know how to
talk to each other that can't be updated
it doesn't work. The leading cause of
anomalies on orbit in space is software
not hardware. And most companies forget
about that. They underinvest in that
space. And by investing in that from the
beginning at Apex, I think we've done a
good job mitigating it. But it's not
just software for the hardware that's on
the satellite or for the satellite
itself. It's software to run the entire
facility. We've had to build our entire
homemade operating system that powers
our entire company that ties together my
BD team with my finance team to supply
chain to production to engineering. That
is the only way we're able to build at
the scale that we're building
at. Anything you want to add, Chris? I
mean, manufacturing is just this
beautiful fun game of getting punched in
the face every single day. Um, I would
say as a startup founder, this and you
know, if anyone's listening who who
wants to start a manufacturing company,
it's it's incredibly important, but it's
not for the uh it's not for the faint of
heart. Um, and the main one is you have
to do this at billions of dollars in
scale, otherwise we don't really fit the
mission, which means you have to grow
unbelievably fast. Um, and most
manufacturing because it's a physical
world companies, it's like growing is
just hard because it's not like a
software company where the faster you
sell, the faster you can deploy because
you just switch on another a data center
server. You have to play this really
nice parallel game of scaling
operations, but not too far ahead of
sales and customer demand and doing the
right thing. And then you've got
workforce development, training. So for
us, the biggest challenge will always be
not producing customer demand, it is
just going to be producing supply as
fast as possible. Um, and it's also
manufacturing, so you get fun things
like there's a fire. Yeah. You know,
there's safety issues. There's there's
all this other stuff. There's, uh, you
know, quality stuff. Um, it's the best
game in the world to play. And arguably,
I think it's the most important thing
for society to be doing is doing
manufacturing in America. But, uh, you
know, it's like you go to get a software
company. I sell him some software.
Great. He uses it. Maybe he writes me a
customer support ticket. You know,
manufacturing is, uh, you know, kinetic.
every and nearly every decision at at
some point could be like game over. It's
like it's all on the line all the time.
Y and I think it's it's maybe there's a
misconception that software is cheaper
than hardware, but it's and I don't
think that's true. It's software the
investment is into the people. So if you
make a big mistake, you can
unfortunately have a layoff and correct
some of that. Um, if you've ever tried
to sell like your used furniture, uh,
versus what you pay versus what you can
sell it for, it's the exact same for
factory equipment, you buy it for
millions and it's literally worth like a
few dollars. Um, you can't reverse any
mistake that you make as you as you go
back. So, you just have to be right. Uh,
which makes it really high stakes. Yep.
I think we're just betting $100 million
chips on capex every single time. And
you got to hope that you're making the
right decision. Yeah. So we have uh a
tremendous amount of policy makers in
the room. What would what would make
your life easier? What could
help? I think the main thing for us in
manufacturing is that
it's you know you raise tariffs, more
things are going to come on shore and
therefore the man manufacturing base is
going to have to grow. Um I think the
two important things are you know big
moves. Um, one
is the DoD has to look at the
manufacturing base like strategic
capability and capacity. Um, you know,
you can go purchase 20,000 drones or
ships or something like that, but
because we've destroyed our industrial
base and talent since kind of the ' 70s
through the '90s of, you know, Nixon
going to China and then kind of NAFTA,
it just takes time to rebuild um,
decades often to that skill base to get
like good again. Um, and I think the
most important thing is policies where
just force more demand on shore, which
is either tariffs or if you're getting
paid by the DoD or the federal
government for a product, your entire
supply chain should be onshored and then
let capitalism figure out how to build
that capacity. I would say the second
most important one is making
manufacturing incredibly sexy and cool
again because you got to remember in the
80s and 90s we told all the kids that if
you did not have a 4-year college
degree, you like, you know, it wasn't
something to be proud of. And that's one
of the biggest impediments that we've
overcome because our factory is really
cool and that matters a lot especially
to 22 and 23 year olds. And if you want
this workforce coming in for the
national mission in ship building or
munitions or fighter jets or drones to
actually make the stuff, uh the cultural
impact that I think the government, the
vice president did a very good job today
of letting kids know that they don't
have to go to a college degree, they can
be an electrician or they can be a
machinist is actually super important
because that's one of the main things of
people not getting started in
manufacturing or defense tech in the
first place is it just has to be cool
and it has to be celebrated. It's true.
And STEM needs to be like actually get
out and make something. Yes. if the
first time you're like actually using a
CNC or a mill is like when you arrive on
the job like you're not going to be a
very good machinist as you would expect.
Ian, what would you what would you add?
So, I mean I think Chris everything you
said is spot on. Um the one thing that I
would add is in my mind the first step
is how do we make sure that uh we're
onoring kind of these capabilities and
these jobs? How do we bring it to the
US? The second step that I think we're
uh just starting to think about now is
how do we make sure the rest of the
world is buying from this US industrial
base. So instead of just selling within
the US, how do we make sure that our
allies around the world are buying from
the US as well? Because frankly, if
they're not able to buy from us, what's
going to happen? They're going to buy
from our nearper adversaries who can
make it much cheaper and much faster. So
for us, we're a huge believer in not
just supporting the US, but supporting
our allies as well. We do a tremendous
amount overseas. We export a lot. Um I
think the tariffs overall have been
positive for us frankly. Uh usually
aerospace is somewhat exempt. But um I
think what we've seen is getting those
export licenses expediently um is
something that has been a huge pain
point where other countries like China
or others are able to do everything
without an export license and swoop in
and try to steal business. What that
does is it degrades the US's capability
to be able to have this influence and
get these capabilities not just in the
US but all over the world. And with that
we have a big red zero on the screen. So
thank you everybody for the time.
Appreciate it.
